subject: Re: quickspelling question
msgSnippet: Write/right - They are, realistically, the same. If you have the Quikscript manual (And if not, you should get it), the numbered letter sequence is
messageBody:
"Write/right" - They are, realistically, the same. If you have the
Quikscript manual (And if not, you should get it), the numbered letter
sequence is #25+#31+#3.

"Science" - Again, the numbered letter sequence = #11+#31+#36+#23+#11.
The last 3 letters (36/23/11) are the sequence you should use when
expressing an "-ance," "-ence" type of suffix.

I hope that helped.

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, Alexander Lampros
<lamproswc@y...> wrote:
> Hey,
>
> Trying to learn quickscript and I had a couple of
> quick spelling questions.
>
> "Write/right": I can't figure out which one of the
> many i/e sounds to use. None of them really seem to
> work.
>
> "Science": Two simple S's?
>
> Cool alphabet, its been fun to learn. Its definitily
> much faster to write, but so far I'm finding it not
> quite as evocative as Roman letters. Maybe once I get
> used to it.
>
> Alex
>
> __________________________________________________
> Do You Yahoo!?
> Tired of spam? Yahoo! Mail has the best spam protection around
> http://mail.yahoo.com

"Write/right" - They are, realistically, the same. If you have the
Quikscript manual (And if not, you should get it), the numbered letter
sequence is #25+#31+#3.

"Science" - Again, the numbered letter sequence = #11+#31+#36+#23+#11.
 The last 3 letters (36/23/11) are the sequence you should use when
expressing an "-ance," "-ence" type of suffix.

I hope that helped.

> work.

> 
> Cool alphabet, its been fun to learn.  Its definitily
> much faster to write, but so far I'm finding it not
> quite as evocative as Roman letters.  Maybe once I get

> Alex
